message: Happy New Year!

Thanks to the calls of outcry this morning by the American people, House Republicans have backpedaled on their plan to move the independent, nonpartisan Office of Congressional Ethics (OCE) under the lawmaker-controlled Committee on Ethics. This move would have undermined the OCE’s independence by allowing the House to halt investigations and stop anonymous reporting.   The OCE was established in 2008 after a series of ethics scandals involving multiple GOP lawmakers. Today, the OCE is dedicated to investigating ethics complaints filed by the public and is essential to ensuring accountability, transparency and trust in our government.   Just this morning, my offices in Lakewood and D.C. received more than 50 phone calls in addition to tweets, Facebook comments and emails from constituents voicing their concern about this move from the Republicans. I encourage everyone to continue to share their thoughts, concerns and ideas with me and my office. Your voice helped change the course of this issue and can continue to have an important impact on issues in the future. Contact my office by calling (303) 274-7944 or email me at https://perlmutter.house.gov/forms/writeyourrep/.
I look forward to continuing to fight for the hardworking people of the 7th District. It is an honor and privilege to represent you in the 115th Congress of the United States of America.

Today Vice President-elect Mike Pence told GOP lawmakers that on day one of the new administration, the President will issue executive orders to repeal the Affordable Care Act. But we still have yet to see a real plan from Republicans to replace Obamacare.   The Republican strategy of ‘Repeal and Delay’ will create uncertainty for millions of Americans, cost taxpayers billions of dollars and do serious damage the healthcare system.   Across the country, Obamacare ended discrimination against people with preexisting conditions, allowed young people to stay on their parents’ coverage until the age of 26 and helped 20 million Americans gain health coverage.  In Colorado, 419,000 people have gained health coverage because of Obamacare. The uninsured rate dropped from 15.9% to 8.1%. Average annual family premium increases were cut from 7% to 4.8%.  Access to health care should not be contingent upon your income bracket or what job you have. The Affordable Care Act is civil rights act, and I will keep fighting to make sure every Coloradan has access to affordable health care.     SOURCE: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services -  http://bit.ly/2j9Hrvv  #ACAworks

It is clear Russia intervened in an attempt to interfere in the 2016 U.S. presidential election. This action by a foreign nation was unprecedented, violated our Constitution and undermined the founding pillars of American liberty and democracy.

I’m cosponsoring the Protecting Our Democracy Act to establish an independent, bipartisan commission to investigate foreign interference in the 2016 election. The bill would create a 12-member commission empowered to interview witnesses, obtain documents, issue subpoenas, and receive public testimony to examine attempts by the Russian government or others to use electronic means to influence, interfere with, or undermine trust in last year’s U.S. elections. The commission would examine any similar efforts by any other foreign governments or entities and would issue a final report with recommendations to Congress and the President within 18 months of enactment.

In addition, Sessions did not provide the clarity needed as it relates to how the federal government will enforce the Controlled Substances Act. In the past, Sessions has favored states’ rights and I would urge the new administration to respect state’s rights on this issue as Congress continues to debate this important issue.

It has been a great privilege to work with President Obama over the last eight years. He brought class and style to the White House, and he will certainly be missed.  #ThanksObama

A conflict of interest, or even the appearance of a conflict of interest, will damage the integrity of the Presidency. Yet, President-elect Trump refuses to sell his business or place his assets in a blind trust while in office.   He is turning over control of the business to his two sons and has promised to have “no involvement whatsoever”. I am concerned this is not enough to reassure the American people that he will act in their best interest rather than in the best interest of the Trump Organization.  The head of the nonpartisan Office of Government Ethics called Trump’s plan “meaningless” and believes it “sets up the incoming administration for constant controversy.”  Additionally, the President-elect has surrounded himself with billionaire and millionaire cabinet officials who also have business dealings across the country and world. The Trump Administration needs to be transparent and honest about how they plan to avoid conflicts of interest at all levels of the administration.

President Trump’s Muslim ban makes us less safe. Today, more than 100 Democratic and Republican national security leaders expressed their “deep concern” saying the “This Order not only jeopardizes tens of thousands of lives, it has caused a crisis right here in America and will do long-term damage to our national security.” Michael Morell, a former deputy director and acting director of the CIA, said “the Trump Executive Order is going to make the threat worse…and is going to make us less safe.”  That’s why I agreed to cosponsor the Statue of Liberty Values Act which makes President Trump’s Executive Order null and void and prohibits the use of funds to implement or enforce any aspect of the Order. We cannot stand idle as this new administration empowers our enemies and jeopardizes the liberty, equality and opportunity the U.S. has afforded immigrants and refugees in the past.

“So what’s the difference with Trump’s action?  "First, Obama responded to an actual threat — the discovery that two Iraqi refugees had been implicated in bombmaking in Iraq that had targeted U.S. troops. (Iraq, after all, was a war zone.) Under congressional pressure, officials decided to reexamine all previous refugees and impose new screening procedures, which led to a slowdown in processing new applications. Trump, by contrast, issued his executive order without any known triggering threat. (His staff has pointed to attacks unrelated to the countries named in his order.)  "Second, Obama did not announce a ban on visa applications. In fact, as seen in Napolitano’s answer to Collins, administration officials danced around that question. There was certainly a lot of news reporting that visa applications had slowed to a trickle. But the Obama administration never said it had a policy to halt all applications. Indeed, it is now clear that no ban was put in place. Even so, the delays did not go unnoticed, so there was a lot of critical news reporting at the time about the angst of Iraqis waiting for approval.  "Third, Obama’s policy did not prevent all citizens of that country, including green-card holders, from traveling to the United States. Trump’s policy is much more sweeping, though officials have appeared to pull back from barring permanent U.S. residents.”

General Michael Flynn’s resignation is an important first step, but there are still many unanswered questions about Russia’s influence on this administration. Why didn’t President Trump act last month when Sally Yates, the Assistant Attorney General, warned the administration Flynn had lied about his conversations with the Russians? Was anyone else from the Trump campaign communicating with Russia prior to the election? What else will turn up in the ongoing FBI investigation? I’m also looking into how General Flynn’s actions violated the Logan Act, a law that prohibits private citizens from conducting diplomacy. Our country deserves answers and I will continue to press the administration for more transparency.  #FlynnResignation

I’m cosponsoring Congressman Jerry Nadler's Resolution of Inquiry directing The United States Department of Justice to provide the House of Representatives with any and all information relevant to an inquiry into President Trump’s conflicts of interest, ethical violations—including of the Emoluments Clause—and Russia ties.  If the Judiciary Committee fails to act on the resolution within 14 days, it becomes a privileged resolution and must be brought to the floor. Additionally, I am joining colleagues on a letter to Chairmen Hatch and Chairman Brady urging their use of authority under the tax code to request President Trump’s tax returns which can be reviewed by the committee in executive session.

Last week four Russian military aircraft buzzed a U.S. destroyer. A Russian spy boat is currently patrolling 30 miles of the coast of Connecticut. Moscow is violating a 1987 bilateral agreement banning ground-launched intermediate-range missiles.  And in the past six months three staff members of President or Nominee Trump have resigned amidst concerns about their ties to Russia. As Americans, it is incumbent on us to investigate Russian’s influence on this administration and our democracy. I call on leaders of the Republican-controlled House and Senate to launch an independent, bipartisan investigation immediately.

I joined the other ranking members of the House Financial Services Committee to send a letter to the Republican Chairmen of the committee requesting an immediate investigation into General Flynn’s ties to Russia. The House Financial Services Committee monitors the implementation of sanctions as well as the activities of Treasury’s Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC). The American people are demanding the truth and it is our duty to investigate this matter.

Last Friday, I had the honor of awarding Buford Johnson with 10 medals and awards he earned but never received from his service to our country during WWII. Private First Class Johnson is a 99-year old Veteran who served in the U.S. Army from June 1943 to September 1945. Several months ago, Mr. Johnson’s daughter reached out to our office to request assistance in obtaining WWII military medals and military personnel file for her father. After reaching out to the National Personnel Records Center, we were able to confirm the medals to which he was entitled, which included the Bronze Star Medal which was not listed on Mr. Johnson’s original discharge certificate. The Bronze Star Medal is the fourth-highest individual military award and the ninth-highest by order of precedence in the US military, and was awarded to Mr. Johnson for meritorious achievement in active ground combat. Being able to honor heroes like Mr. Johnson is a privilege and a highlight for my office. Thank you Mr. Johnson for your service to our country.

Since taking office, President Trump and his Administration have been focused on everything but the economy. Their initial unrealistic and harmful policies have created confusion and uncertainty. Many questions remain as to the direction the President intends to steer our country.     Yet I remain focused on building economic opportunity for Coloradans. This means fighting for good paying jobs with increasing incomes, reducing the student loan burden, making housing more affordable, and ensuring hardworking families have the opportunity to thrive.  I believe we can find common ground with the White House and Congress on issues like infrastructure, tax reform, aerospace, and job creation. But I will continue to hold the Administration accountable when their policies harm Colorado’s economy or infringe on the freedoms and values Coloradans cherish.  This last month has shown our democracy can be fragile and we all need to safeguard it at every level. As Coloradans and as Americans, we all have a responsibility to protect the liberty, equality and opportunity we enjoy. #JointAddress

I’m shocked to learn Attorney General Sessions did not disclose his communications with Russian officials during the presidential campaign. With AG Sessions now at the center of this investigation, it’s clear he cannot be trusted to conduct a full and fair investigation into the ties between Trump officials and Russia. Furthermore, as a lawyer and a member of the Bar Association, AG Sessions has an obligation to avoid any appearance of impropriety and this standard appears to have been breached. A special prosecutor needs to be appointed immediately in order to lead a neutral investigation and get to the bottom of this.   This certainly leads us to wonder what the President, the Attorney General and the Administration are hiding. Congressional Republicans have continued to obstruct the process to investigate ties between Russia and President Trump and his officials.    The American people deserve nothing less than an independent, thorough investigation because we cannot allow a foreign nation to have undue influence over our democracy.

Millions of people have healthcare coverage due to the Affordable Care Act, including hundreds of thousands in Colorado. While I’m open to improving the law, I will fight against any effort to roll back the progress we’ve already made. Early estimates show the current Republican replacement plan could leave 10 million people without healthcare coverage while others are forced to pay more for less care. My responsibility is to ensure the hardworking folks in my district can access affordable healthcare coverage without being left bankrupt or without care in a time of need. That’s why I will continue to fight for a healthcare system that includes the basics such as protecting individuals with preexisting conditions, allowing young adults to stay on their parents’ plan until age 26, no lifetime limits on care, capping out-of-pocket expenses, and strengthening Medicare.
Taking health coverage away from poor and lower income Americans will not make America great again.

Today I Introduced legislation that would enable individuals and companies to take legal action against corporate corruption. Current law only allows the Department of Justice (DOJ) and the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to bring enforcement actions under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA).    Given the new leadership at the DOJ and SEC, this legislation is more important than ever. Corruption and bribery undermine the pillars of democracy and erode trust. The potential for lack of oversight for foreign corruption is a serious concern given President Trump, his family business, and his surrogates’ questionable business ties.   President Trump has failed to meaningfully divest or sever ties with the Trump Organization, and his family continues to enrich themselves by seeking business deals all over the world. This presents conflicts of interest, but also potentially violates the FCPA and the emoluments clause of the U.S. Constitution. We must hold them and other bad actors accountable.

The President’s budget proposes eliminating the Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) program which helps fund Meals on Wheels and other programs like it. CDBG funding represents 0.08% of the total federal budget. To put this in perspective, if the federal budget was a 100 yard football field, CDBG funding would represent about 3 inches.   About 4000 seniors in the Denver metro area rely on Meals on Wheels to be able to continue living in their own homes. A couple years ago I had the opportunity to help deliver meals around the 7th Congressional District, and I can tell you this program makes a world of difference for older Coloradans. President Trump’s proposed budget will have devastating consequences for our country and for Colorado. I will do my best to fight against the cuts affecting hardworking families, federal employees, businesses and research organizations.

Today the FBI confirmed it is investigating possible coordination between the Trump campaign and Russia. If this administration has nothing to hide, it should cooperate fully with the FBI’s investigation. In addition, I continue to call for an independent special prosecutor to look into this issue. FBI Director James Comey also clarified that, despite President Trump’s tweets, there is zero evidence that Trump Tower was wiretapped by President Obama. These baseless claims made by President Trump have taken up enough congressional resources and it’s time to refocus on the serious issue at-hand: President Trump and his team’s ties to Russia.

Officials from the Colorado Association of Transit Agencies (CASTA) and the Regional Transportation District (RTD) were in Washington D.C. this week to present the award. I’m proud to have helped secure federal funding for construction of RTD’s West Line as well as federal funds as a part of RTD’s Eagle Public Private Partnership to construct the A, B, and G Lines.  My office has also hosted “Commuting with your Congressman” events in 2015 and 2016 to visit with constituents at rail stations or on board the West Line on their way to work. My constituents are always looking for more efficient ways to travel to and from work and throughout the metro area.  I will continue working to ensure we have strong transit choices in our transportation system so Coloradans can move more freely across the state.

This month the House unanimously passed H.R. 1367 to improve hiring at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Included in this bill was the creation of an Executive Management Fellowship Program which was thought up by one of my constituents, Karthik Venkatraj, from Westminster. Karthik recently traveled to DC with the Veterans of Foreign Wars and told me about his idea. This fellowship program will allow senior managers at the VA to work in a comparable position in the private sector for one year to learn best practices, while also allowing employees from the private sector to work within the VA for one year to offer their perspective on how to improve delivery of healthcare and benefits to Veterans. Thank you Karthik for your work on this fellowship program and I look forward to seeing this program signed into law and beginning to improve the VA.

Republicans have spent the last seven years criticizing and undermining the ACA. Thankfully they were unsuccessful in pushing through their disastrous bill but in the process they managed to scare and create uncertainty for hardworking families who depend on affordable health coverage. This is a serious issue, and a matter of life and death for many. It is time the White House and Congressional Republicans come to the table and work with Democrats to improve the ACA. #ProtectOurCare

Yesterday, my office held a ceremony to honor and recognize Vietnam-era Veterans from Colorado who served on active duty in the U.S. Armed Forces between November 1, 1955 and May 15, 1975. Each Veteran was awarded a Vietnam Veteran Lapel Pin and a certificate from Governor John W. Hickenlooper's office. Over the next several months, my office will be hosting seven additional ceremonies to honor a total of nearly 600 Vietnam-era Veterans in Colorado.  I am honored to be able to recognize these Veterans and thank them for their service to our country. I also want to thank Major General Michael Edwards, the Adjutant General of Colorado, Army Brigadier General John Rose and U.S. Army Captain Michael Schreckengost for their help with the ceremony.  The ceremony is part of The United States of America Vietnam War Commemoration. This program began with the Presidential inaugural event at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington D.C. on Memorial Day, May 28, 2012, and concludes on Veterans Day, November 11, 2025.   The Department of Veterans Affairs estimates that today there are 7 million living Vietnam Veterans and 9 million families of those who served in this time frame. According to the VA, as of 2014, there are more than 127,000 Vietnam-era Veterans living in Colorado. The Commemoration does not distinguish between Veterans who served in-country, in-theater, or who were stationed elsewhere during the Vietnam War period.  #Vietnam50

President Trump’s decision to roll back the progress we’ve made combating climate change is short-sided and a bad move for our economy. The Clean Power Plan and the many other protections put in place over the last eight years are good for our national security, good for the climate, and good for jobs. I believe we can do both – improve our energy independence and create good paying jobs. Colorado has been a leader in energy efficiency and clean energy and we have realized substantial economic benefits for Colorado through innovation, research and development, and the creation of jobs. #CleanPowerPlan #ActOnClimate

Thank you to the 651 Coloradans who participated in my survey. I've heard from nearly 100 constituents since the beginning of the year who are concerned that President Trump has not released his tax returns. And a recent poll conducted by the Global Strategy Group found that 80% of Americans still want to see the President’s tax returns.  Earlier this year, I joined 163 of my colleagues to call on Senate Finance Chairman Orrin Hatch and Ways and Means Chairman Kevin Brady to use their authority to request President Trump’s tax returns. As hardworking Americans file their taxes by today’s deadline, I continue to call on the President to be transparent with the American people and release his tax returns.

In President Trump’s latest executive order signed yesterday, he ordered a review of the H-1B visa program which brings high-skilled foreign workers to the U.S. The current H-1B program admits 85,000 foreign workers annually primarily in the high-tech, industrial, medical and science fields. Earlier this year, the Trump Administration suspended expedited processing of H-1B visa applications which went into effect April 3.  With one of the nation’s highest concentrations of high-tech employees and thousands of high-tech companies, Colorado relies on the H-1B program to fill critical positions and grow local businesses. Colorado also relies on the program to help attract students and scholars at its universities and research facilities.  We must continue to develop job training programs for American workers to make sure they can compete globally for the jobs of today and the future, but this executive order only causes uncertainty for high-skilled workers and the U.S. companies that depend on them.

We will never forget the 13 lives that were lost and the families, friends, and loved ones who were impacted by the senseless act of violence that took place at Columbine High School 18 years ago. The tragedy was devastating to my family, our community, and our country. We continue to honor those lives we lost on that fateful day today and every day.

I urge President Trump and Republican leaders in Congress to stop undermining the ACA and threatening healthcare for Coloradans.

The 145,000 square foot expansion will house design facilities, product manufacturing, test ranges and administrative space, and is expected to be completed by spring 2019. Today a federal judge in California temporarily blocked the Trump administration’s efforts to withhold funding from so-called sanctuary cities. There are over 100 cities and counties across the U.S. that limit their cooperation with federal immigration enforcement and instead choose to support their immigrant communities, including several in Colorado.  I believe we must treat all residents equally and fairly and work to address the larger issue of comprehensive immigration reform. I support comprehensive reform that will fix our broken system, create American jobs, lower our deficit, strengthen our borders, and give undocumented Americans an earned pathway to citizenship.

New findings show that former National Security Advisor Michael Flynn did not comply with the law when he did not disclose pertinent information on his security clearance application form. The House Oversight Committee has tried to look into the matter but the White House has refused to comply with their requests for Flynn’s security clearance applications and other documents.  I continue to call for the immediate appointment of a special prosecutor to lead an independent and thorough investigation. We cannot let the White House or Congressional Republicans obstruct the process to investigate ties between Russia and President Trump and his officials. It’s time to get to the bottom of this.

Today President Trump signed an executive order to review more than 20 years of national monument designations in the U.S., including the Canyons of the Ancients which was declared a national monument by President Clinton in 2000. Colorado is home to eight national monuments encompassing more than 440,000 acres.  In Colorado, we value these public lands and they are a significant contributor to our state’s economy. We need to protect our public lands and national treasures, not find ways to roll back those protections.

With eight states and Washington, D.C. now allowing for adult-use recreational marijuana and 29 states legalizing medical marijuana, it is time to align federal and state laws - specifically as it relates to the banking crisis confronting marijuana-related businesses. That's why I'm introducing bipartisan legislation to allow marijuana-related businesses in states with existing regulatory structures to access the banking system.  The Secure and Fair Enforcement Banking Act (SAFE Banking Act) ensures financial institutions can service marijuana-related businesses without the fear of reprisal from the federal government. The legislation will ensure all small businesses and their employees are treated fairly. Most importantly, the SAFE Banking Act reduces the public safety threat that arises when small businesses are forced to operate on a cash-only basis.   With the majority of states now allowing for some form of recreational or medical marijuana, we have reached a tipping point on this issue and it’s time for Congress to act.

In addition to signing a new executive order to roll back restrictions on offshore oil and gas drilling, President Trump was also granted his request to halt a lawsuit over the Clean Power Plan today. The Trump Administration had asked the D.C. Court of Appeals to stop deliberations so they could take another look at the rule which would have required power plants to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions. Now the Clean Power Plan heads back to the EPA under President Trump where it will likely be repealed once and for all.  If the Clean Power Plan were fully implemented, carbon pollution could be reduced by 870 million tons and pollutants that make Americans sick could be cut by more than 20% by 2030.  I supported President Obama’s work on the Clean Power Plan and other initiatives to combat climate change, and will continue to fight against President Trump’s actions to roll back the progress we’ve made.

For the third weekend in a row, people will march across the country to stand up against President Trump and his policies. In his first 100 days in office, President Trump has taken aim at several environmental protections and started rolling back efforts to combat climate change such as targeting the Clean Power Plan, funding cuts to U.S. science and environmental agencies, review of national monument designations, and expanded offshore drilling.  I applaud those who are taking an active role in our democracy and participating in these demonstrations, including the People’s Climate March today. An interested citizenry makes a democracy stronger.

In 1963, President Lyndon B. Johnson established National Small Business Week to recognize the contributions of small, independently owned businesses.   According to the Small Business Administration, in Colorado, there are more than 596,000 small businesses which employ about 1.1 million people. The three industries in Colorado with the most small business employment include accommodation and food services, health care and social assistance and construction. Across the country, more than half of Americans own or work for a small business, creating around two out of every three net new jobs in the United States.  Entrepreneurship is a key driver of economic growth in our communities and small businesses are vital for American innovation and prosperity. #COSBW

Today I join with my Democratic colleagues to fight back against Republican attempts to repeal Dodd-Frank and vital consumer protections.   I’m proud of the work I did to secure passage of Dodd-Frank in 2010 because it helped hold Wall Street and big banks more accountable and protect our country from another financial crisis. Most importantly, Dodd-Frank established the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) which restores responsibility to American taxpayers and protects consumers. The agency has already returned about $12 billion to consumers over the last six years. But now the Republicans’ #WrongCHOICEAct would gut the CFPB and limit consumer protections.  We cannot go back to the days before the 2008 financial crisis. I will continue to fight for hardworking Coloradans and consumers across this country to ensure everyone is able to secure a better future for themselves and their families.

As Republicans continue their efforts to repeal Dodd-Frank, I offered an amendment to prohibit federal banking regulators from implementing the #WrongChoiceAct until President Trump releases his tax returns. The American people should be able to certify that new banking regulations will not directly or indirectly benefit President Trump, his businesses or his friends. The only way to fully understand President Trump’s conflicts of interest is if he releases his tax returns.  Transparency is key to a functioning democracy and without fully knowing the full picture of President Trump’s financial dealings, we should not be passing laws that could benefit his creditors, his friends or his businesses.

I’m pleased that Congress was able to work in a bipartisan fashion to avert a shutdown and fund the government through September 30, 2017. However it is alarming that President Trump is already calling for a “shutdown” in future budget negotiations. The work of running and funding the government is a serious matter and shouldn’t be joked about or threatened by the President.   While we were able to prevent deep budget cuts this time around, I remain concerned that President Trump's budget will have a profound impact on our economy in Colorado. I will continue to push back and fight against cuts to important Colorado priorities such as transportation, education, NASA, NREL, NIH and other research and development funding.

Today Republicans will try again to repeal the Affordable Care Act. Their replacement bill will harm the most vulnerable Americans and fails to address rising costs of health care. It will weaken the health care system in rural Colorado and attacks protections for people with preexisting conditions. 24 million Americans will lose coverage.  I am voting NO. #VoteNoAHCA

The Republican plan to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act has gone from bad to worse. Protecting people with preexisting conditions was at the heart of the ACA and eliminating this protection is eliminating a civil right. Each of us knows someone with a preexisting condition and failing to ensure adequate coverage for our neighbors, friends and family is unacceptable and immoral.    Under the Republican plan, states will be able to opt out of requiring insurance companies to provide Essential Health Benefits which includes maternity and pediatric services, outpatient care, substance abuse and mental health treatment and prescription drug coverage. This plan puts tens of millions of Americans at risk of losing their health insurance coverage and it discriminates against seniors through higher rates.    By all accounts, Coloradans will suffer if this bill becomes law. This plan takes us backward and is a bad deal for millions of hardworking families who have come to rely on affordable, quality health insurance.

This week, Republicans on the House Financial Services Committee tried to advance legislation that would roll back consumer and investor protections in the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act. Their legislation would repeal critical safeguards in Dodd-Frank and unleash the same behavior on Wall Street that led to the 2008 financial crisis.  I helped pass Dodd-Frank in 2010 to hold Wall Street and big banks more accountable and protect our country from another financial crisis. Dodd-Frank also established the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) – the only federal agency with the sole mission of protecting consumers in the financial marketplace.  We put Dodd-Frank in place to bring some discipline to the financial markets and since then, on average, we’ve been gaining 200,000 jobs a month and we continue to see sizable gains in the stock market. There are times you have to have discipline to protect people. Repealing Dodd-Frank will bring back a wild west approach to financial regulation and we cannot go back to those days. #WrongChoiceAct

I was honored to receive the Lion Advocacy Award at this year's Colorado Education Association Luncheon. I believe in the importance of public education and the freedom and opportunity it can provide for young people. And we can never forget that education is at the heart of a democracy.   Our teachers and educators play a critical role in educating and shaping our children today, tomorrow and well into the future. I want to thank all the teachers in our community, in our state and across the country for the commitment you show our children every day. We appreciate you. #ThankATeacher

Today is Teacher Appreciation Day - a day to honor and recognize the contributions teachers make in all of our lives. Each teacher influences students in his or her own way in the classroom. Each of us were impacted by our teachers when we were growing up, and it is their dedication and hard work that inspires us to continue to achieve our goals.   Being a teacher is a tough job, but it is also one of the most important. We all have teachers who encouraged us, counseled us, and helped to shape our lives in a positive way. A quality education is the foundation for a strong future both individually and as a nation. Myself as well as all six of my and my wife’s kids attended Jefferson County Public Schools where we received an excellent education that helped prepare us for the future. We also left with many fond memories of our teachers.   To all the hardworking teachers out there - including my wife and sister, I want to say "thank you." #ThankATeacher

The timing of President Trump's decision to fire FBI Director James Comey is concerning. Clearly, President Trump is hiding something. Despite Attorney General Jeff Sessions vowing to recuse himself from all Russia-related investigations, President Trump acted on a recommendation from AG Sessions to remove Director Comey - the very person that was leading an investigation into Russian interference into the 2016 election and President Trump's ties to Russia.  This Administration cannot be trusted to handle any part of this investigation and they must be separated from any ongoing investigation immediately. It is now more important than ever that an independent special prosecutor is appointed to take over this investigation. The future of our democracy and the American people deserve for this process to be handled in a serious, non-political manner.

Reforming our nation's immigration system is a critical issue. President Trump and his surrogates’ cozy relationship with Russian officials has always been concerning but his alleged sharing of sensitive and classified information with Russian officials is alarming and constitutes a serious national security risk. The Trump Administration’s erratic and dysfunctional nature plus a lack of transparency when it comes to their Russian ties is jeopardizing our security and democracy. Now more than ever, we need an independent investigation.

If true, President Trump’s own statement shows he tried to directly influence the Justice Department and FBI investigation into his ties to Russia. This is outrageous. People need to know what is going on and the only way to do that is with an independent investigation without interference or influence from President Trump or his administration.   Mr. President, we are not letting this go. #ComeyMemo

I just added my name to launch a discharge petition to force a vote on H.R. 356, the Protecting Our Democracy Act. This bill will establish an independent, bipartisan commission to investigate Trump-Russia ties and interference in the 2016 presidential election.   Just in the last week, we have seen President Trump fire FBI Director Comey, leak classified intel to Russia, and allegedly try to influence the FBI’s investigation into his ties with Russia. It’s time for Democrats and Republicans to come together to create an independent outside commission and an independent counsel to get to the bottom of this. #CountryBeforeParty

After calling for an independent investigation for months, I am pleased to see the DOJ appoint former FBI Director Robert Mueller as special counsel. This is a step in the right direction to ensure a thorough and independent investigation. #TrumpRussia

Tomorrow, May 20, Colorado celebrates Colorado Public Lands Day. In May 2016, Colorado became the first state in the nation to establish a holiday recognizing the value of public lands to our state. Colorado Public Lands Day will now occur on the third Saturday in May each year.   Over the past several months, my office has heard from a number of constituents through phone calls, emails, and in-person meetings voicing their support for protecting our public lands. This is an important issue for many Coloradans.  All across our state, Coloradans value their connection to the outdoors, and we are lucky to have some of the best outdoor recreation in the country. For me personally, I enjoy jumping on my bike and going for a ride. Or when I go up to the mountains, I'm sure to bring either my skis or my fishing rod. There's nothing better than spending time outside and connecting with the outdoors.  For more information about all the events taking place tomorrow, visit copubliclandsday.com. #CoPublicLandsDay

At the start of the new Congress, I said I would look for ways to work with the President and the Republican majority on issues where we could find common ground including infrastructure, creating good-paying jobs and growing our economy. During the campaign, the President promised to help hardworking Americans by focusing on these issues, but more than 100 days in to his presidency, President Trump has focused on anything but these issues.   The American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) rated our nation's infrastructure at a D+ and shows that our country faces a $2 trillion 10-year gap in infrastructure investment. The price of failing to build, maintain, and repair our infrastructure is costing American families $3,400 dollars each year in disposable income and will jeopardize 2.5 million jobs between now and 2025.  Infrastructure connects us and our communities, and it's imperative we keep up with our needs to promote commerce, create jobs and improve the quality of life. #InvestInAmerica #TimeToBuild

I cannot support a budget that among other things proposes deep cuts to the National Renewable Energy Lab (NREL), environmental protections and education programs such as financial aid, Head Start and after-school programs.  I will continue to fight against cuts affecting hardworking families, federal employees, businesses, universities and research organizations.

I felt it necessary to join this lawsuit because President Trump refuses to separate himself from his business interests and release his tax returns. Tomorrow morning, NASA's Cassini Mission to Saturn will end its remarkable journey. In dramatic fashion, Cassini will plunge into Saturn’s atmosphere so as not to contaminate its moons that could potentially harbor life. The mission dates back to the 1980s but was ultimately launched in 1997 and has been studying Saturn, its rings, moons and magnetosphere since 2004. In its final moments, Cassini will dive deeper into the atmosphere of Saturn than ever before.  As a joint project between NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the European Space Agency (ESA) and the Italian Space Agency, the mission also delivered ESA’s Huygens probe to Titan, one of Saturn’s moons, in 2005. Huygens was the first landing on a world in the outer solar system.  Cassini was the first spacecraft to visit Saturn since the flyby of Voyager 2 in 1981. With the end of Cassini, there is no other mission currently operating or under development to visit Saturn or its moons.  Watch live coverage of Cassini’s end on NASA TV starting at 7am EDT on Friday, September 15 - https://www.nasa.gov/nasalive.

I would like to congratulate Dennison Elementary School in Lakewood for being awarded as a Blue Ribbon School. In March 2013, I sent a letter to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives (ATF) asking the agency to ban any gun product which allows for semiautomatic assault rifles to function as fully automatic. In April 2013, ATF sent a response stating that they do not “have the authority to restrict their [bump-fire stocks] lawful possession, use or transfer.”   I sent a letter to Speaker Ryan this week to make him aware of my 2013 exchange with the ATF and to urge him to bring legislation banning bump stocks to the floor of the House for a vote. Congress needs to act to make the law crystal clear and ban these dangerous products once and for all.

The future of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) is in jeopoardy. I helped craft parts of the Dodd-Frank legislation which created the CFPB and strongly believe the agency and its mission must remain intact.  Since 2011, the CFPB has returned almost $12 billion to nearly 30 million consumers who have been harmed by unfair, deceptive, and abusive acts or practices by financial institutions. This includes bad actors like Wells Fargo which set up millions of fraudulent accounts. CFPB has also handled over 1.3 million consumer complaints about financial products and services, such as problems with credit reporting, private education loans, and residential mortgage loans, and it has issued new rules to ensure consumers are not victims of discriminatory and predatory practices.   Before Dodd-Frank, consumer protection was handled by seven different federal agencies. Today, the CFPB is an independent watchdog solely focused on helping protect consumers from the same bad practices that contributed to the 2008 financial crisis. #DefendCFPB
